questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the hospital with bleeding wound from bite of his pet dog which was fully vaccinated. He previously had completed anti rabies immunization on December 2018. What post exposure prophylaxis against rabies is recommended for the patient now?

options.label: B
options.text: Single site 2 doses on day 0 and 3

options.label: C
options.text: Single site 4 doses on day 0, 3, 7 and 28

questions.correct_answer: B. Single site 2 doses on day 0 and 3
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Single site 2 doses on day 0 and 3

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: For the following question, there is an Assertion - (A) and Reasoning - (R) statement. Mark the correct/true option as per the following direction - Select one of the following: Assertion – (A): WHO recommends Typhoid vaccine in endemic areas in disaster management Reason – (R): Vaccines are cost effective way to deal with disease prevention in endemic areas

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements, but the Reason is not the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true / correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false / incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement WHO clearly states that typhoid and cholera vaccination is not indicated in disaster management. Therefore reason is correct.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: For the following question, there is an Assertion - (A) and Reasoning - (R) statement. Mark the correct/true option as per the following direction: Select one of the following: Assertion – (A): Malathion used in dengue control as anti-adult in ULV fogging Reason – (R): Malathion has residual effect as an insecticide

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements, but the Reason is not the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true / correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false / incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the true / correct explanation for the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the true / correct explanation for the Assertion

Highyeild:

ULV (ultra low volume) fogging is a technique in which cold fogging machines use large volumes of air at low pressures to transform liquid into droplets that are dispersed into the atmosphere. Vector control methods for dengue include malathion fogging for adult vector control as it is insecticidal to the adult aedes aegypti mosquito.

questions.text: A study is to be designed to understand the correct technique for injection by a health care professional. The best way to assess will be:

options.label: A
options.text: In depth Interview with the patient

options.label: B
options.text: In depth Interview with the health care provider

questions.correct_answer: D. Questionnaire based with checklist
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Questionnaire based with checklist Direct observation with structure checklist is the best method to survey the injection practice of health workers.

Highyeild:

Seven Rights for Safe Injection Delivery: Right medication Right dose Right patient and site Right time Right route of administration Right documentation Right disposal Injection can be delivered through different methods: The injections are commonly classified by the target tissue (e.g. intradermal, subcutaneous, intramuscular, intravenous, intraosseous, intra-arterial and peritoneal). Intradermal Injection: A shallow injection given between the layers of the skin, creating a "weal" on the skin. Steps for administering the intradermal injection Assemble equipment and check physicians older. Explain procedure to patient Perform hand wash and use disposable gloves. If necessary, withdraw medication from the ampoule or vial. Select an area on the inner aspect of the forearm that is not heavily pigmented or covered with hair. The upper chest or upper back beneath the scapulae are also sites for intradermal injections. Cleanse the area with an alcohol swab by wiping with a firm circular motion and moving outward from the injection site. Allow skin to dry. Use your non-dominant hand to pull skin taut over the injection site. Remove needle cap with non-dominant hand by pulling it straight off. Place the needle almost flat against the patient’s skin, bevel side up. Insert the needle so that the point of the needle can be seen through the skin--only about 1/8 of an inch. Slowly inject agent while watching for a small wheal or buster to appear. If none appears, withdraw the needle slightly. Withdraw the needle at the same angle it was inserted. Do not massage the area after removing the needle. Do not recap the used needle. Discard the needle and syringe in the appropriate receptacle. Assist the patient into a position of comfort. Remove your gloves and dispose them properly. Perform hand hygiene. Chart the administration of medication, as well as the site of the administration. Some agencies recommend circling the injection site with ink. Observe the area for signs of reaction at ordered intervals.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a specific protection method under primary level of prevention?

options.label: A
options.text: Ribavirin to close contact meningitis patient

options.label: D
options.text: Addition of iron with Wheat flour

questions.correct_answer: B. Health education about hand washing
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Health education about hand washing Option A, C, D are examples or primary prevention (specific protection), but option B is an example of primordial prevention.

Highyeild:

Primary prevention is done when the risk is present, but the disease has not yet appeared.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

a = 2 / b = 1 / c = 5 / d = 3

questions.text: What is the numerator in perinatal mortality?

options.label: B
options.text: Still birth after 28 weeks of gestation

options.label: C
options.text: Neonatal death up to 28 days after birth

questions.correct_answer: B. Still birth after 28 weeks of gestation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Still birth after 28 weeks of gestation

Highyeild:

Perinatal mortality rate: (No. of deaths occurring after 28weeks of gestation and within 7days after delivery/ total no. of live birth) X 1000 At 28 weeks of gestation weight of the infant is expected to be 1000gms.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for influenza?

options.label: B
options.text: Virus shedding present before the patient presents with symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: 1 to 5 years is high risk age group

questions.correct_answer: C. 1 to 5 years is high risk age group
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 to 5 years is high risk age group Options A, B and D are true statements.

Highyeild:

Influenza is an infectious disease caused by influenza viruses. Symptoms range from mild to severe and often include fever, runny nose, sore throat, muscle pain, headache, coughing, and fatigue. These symptoms begin from one to four days after exposure to the virus (typically two days) and last for about 2–8 days. Diarrhea and vomiting can occur, particularly in children. Influenza may progress to pneumonia, which can be caused by the virus or by a subsequent bacterial infection. Other complications of infection include acute respiratory distress syndrome, meningitis, encephalitis, and worsening of pre-existing health problems such as asthma and cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: WHO recommended mass drug administration is indicated for all except:
questions.correct_answer: B. Vitamin A deficiency
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin A deficiency

Highyeild:

Mass drug therapy (WHO criteria) Filariasis : DEC + albendazole Worm infestation : Albendazole Scabies: Ivermectin + Azithromycin Mass drug administration (MDA) is the administration of a drug to an entire concerned population irrespective of age and gender. Vitamin A prophylaxis is given under NIS only to children upto 5 years. Therefore it is not considered under MDA.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: Indicator for vector burden on human malaria is:
questions.correct_answer: A. Man biting rate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Man biting rate Man biting rate is number of mosquito bites per man, this tells us the no. of mosquitoes per human which is nothing but the vector burden.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. A commonly used measure of malaria transmission intensity is the entomological inoculation rate (EIR), defined as the product of the human biting rate (HBR) and sporozoite infection rate (SIR). The EIR excludes molecular parameters that may influence vector control and surveillance strategies. Option C. The slide positivity rate (SPR), defined as the number of laboratory-confirmed malaria cases per 100 suspected cases examined, provides an alternative method for estimating temporal changes in malaria incidence. Option D. The Human Blood Index (HBI) represents the proportion of blood meals derived from humans by mosquito vectors. It may be used to estimate the human biting habit, an impor- tant component of vectorial capacity, as a proxy measure of malaria transmission.

questions.text: Intensified malaria control under the national framework for malaria elimination is defined as:

options.label: D
options.text: 3 consecutive years no local transmission in the state

questions.correct_answer: A. States with API >1
questions.explanation:
Solution:

States with API >1

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Zero incidence of malaria is criteria for prevention of re-establishment. Option C: Malaria is still a health problem. Option D: 3 consecutive years of no local transmission is not a criteria.

questions.text: In India cause of death can be assessed by: Medical death certificate Census Death reporting SRS Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.correct_answer: B. If 1 and 3 are correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If 1 and 3 are correct

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false. Line 1C in medical death certificate speaks about cause of death. We cannot know about the cause of death in census, we can get to know total population, sex ratio, caste ratio, etc with census. Death reporting, may regarded as method for evaluation of cause of death because it involves in verbal autopsy. SRS (sample registration system) In this we can get to know about crude birth rate, crude death rate, IMR, MMR, etc but cause of death cannot be identified.
